pullRequest.body:
This PR "completes" the checks implied by `assert_not_exists` and `assert_not_imported`: at the time of using one of those commands, the declarations/imports are not present in the environment.

Now, each time that one of the commands above is used, the information is recorded in the environment, so that running `#check_assertions` reports the status of each one.

If `#check_assertions` finds that something is still missing, then it emits a warning, otherwise it just logs the report.

The `#check_assertions!` variant is silent unless some declaration/import is missing and, in that case, it only prints what is missing.  This is useful for testing.

There is also the extra file `test/AssertImported.lean` consisting of
```lean
import Mathlib

#check_assertions!
```
to make sure that CI fails if there are non-existing imports/declarations.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [92b0c701fe](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16002/commits/92b0c701fef939919fa4927ef4f7b1352ad1ebf7)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Util.AssertExists | 2 | 4 | +2 (+100.00%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
There are 4374 files with changed transitive imports taking up over 182121 characters: this is too many to display!
You can run `scripts/import_trans_difference.sh all` locally to see the whole output.

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ AssertExists`
`+ Lean.Environment.getSortedAssertExists`
`+ Nats`
`+ addDeclEntry`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/ad8d5724-91f3-4de1-a24c-8080d49c780b) for commit 96be2839c7d2031c1a6d74d75b1b05502f6164d2.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/46539701-31e2-41f9-9682-44c61ac3c895/to/ad8d5724-91f3-4de1-a24c-8080d49c780b) against commit 182970f706c876b68c7c32c1c96f1f5732ad55a4.

Actually, the CI step is already embedded in the tests: one of the files calls the `#check_assertions!` command with `import Mathlib`: the command is noisy if and only if there are non-existent declarations or imports.

> Actually, the CI step is already embedded in the tests: one of the files calls the `#check_assertions!` command with `import Mathlib`: the command is noisy if and only if there are non-existent declarations or imports.

I kinda liked the previous incarnation. I think this is good for an initial commit so I don't think we should go back now but the feedback in CI for failure was a bit earlier. 

Aside: why are we building the archive and counterexamples so high up in the workflow?

> > Actually, the CI step is already embedded in the tests: one of the files calls the `#check_assertions!` command with `import Mathlib`: the command is noisy if and only if there are non-existent declarations or imports.
> 
> I kinda liked the previous incarnation. I think this is good for an initial commit so I don't think we should go back now but the feedback in CI for failure was a bit earlier.

This is very easy: it just suffices to add a step that builds `test/AssertImported`, failing if there is any sort of output.  Let me know if you want me to add it back in this PR or in a follow up.

> Aside: why are we building the archive and counterexamples so high up in the workflow?

I do not know the reason for this, but both steps are relatively short.

In fact, I had it in the back of my mind to run `Archive`, `Counterexamples`, `tests` and `linting` in parallel, as soon as the cache has been checked.  Each would be its own separate workflow that downloads the cache and does its thing.  What stopped me from implementing this was that I could not find a way to make the github actions contingent on the success of a *different* action.  The issue might have been that the logic for this was supposed to be on `master` and could not be tested on a branch.

Thanks for bearing with me!

bors merge
Thank you very much for the reviews: I really feel that the code improved a lot!

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10496570074/job/29077517792)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10496570074/job/29077518083)

I think it looks good! Thanks. 

Is the CI step coming later?
I think a `try ... catch` block is more natural here.

```suggestion
  let decl 
    try liftCoreM <| realizeGlobalConstNoOverloadWithInfo n
    catch _ => return .anonymous
```

```suggestion
    catch _ => return Name.anonymous
```

```suggestion
  let decl  try liftCoreM <| realizeGlobalConstNoOverloadWithInfo n
    catch _ => 
      Mathlib.AssertNotExist.addDeclEntry true n.getId
      return
```
:facepalm: Thanks!  I can then remove the awkward `if ... .anonymous ... then ... else`!

Actually, `return` does not work, since I should return a name.  I still added the declaration to the environment inside the catch, since that allows to only run the rest of the code in the non-`anonymous` branch.
Sorry. I don't understand.
Actually, it was I who did not understand: I had added a `:=` before the `` and then I had to return a `Name`.  Removing the `:=` allowed for the slicker code that you suggested.

```suggestion
  let entries := assertExistsExt.getState env |>.toArray.qsort fun d e => (e.isDecl < d.isDecl) ||
      (e.isDecl == d.isDecl && (d.givenName.toString < e.givenName.toString))
```
This could conceivably be a method in the file where the extension is declared.

I like this suggestion and added `getSortedAssertExists` to the extension file.  I also moved there the `addDeclEntry` function: I did not place it there before, since I thought that this was what causing the `lake build` issues.  I had not realized that the issue was the `olean` explosion.

```suggestion
  for d in entries do
```
This logic makes me think there should only be one command that handles both declarations and imports.
Hmm the comment wasn't focused correctly. I mean the `if d.isDecl` branching
They are very similar, yes, but how would Lean know if what you are asserting not to exist is a declaration or an import?
If there happened to be collision, I would make sure both don't exist and let the error disambiguate if that failed. But this is not in scope here. Just a comment.
Do you use `cond` outside the loop?
I think that you are right, I can probably do `let cond := if ...`.  A previous version had more stuff in the `if` branch, so I had to `mut`ate `cond` as well, but now it seems unnecessary.

Do you want this to live in the `Lean.Environment` namespace for access to dot notation? (This seems standard.) 

Optional suggestion: sorting could be a boolean parameter you pass. Either is fine to me.

I put `getSortedAssertExists` in the `Lean.Environment` namespace.

I did not do the optional sorting, since the `HashSet`s produce random orderings and for both `#guard_msgs` and retrieving information about a specific declaration/import it is convenient to know where to look.
Maybe end the namespace and start a new one? I think `_root_` is frowned upon.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: `assert_not_exists` and `assert_not_imported` checks
